item.title: Build and Analyze 97: Grapefruits Everywhere

item.description: Dan and Marco discuss Nests, Mac App Store review times, iOS 6 upgrades, non-Retina support, managing servers for app back-ends, and whether perpetual app maintenance is necessary.

item.title: The Incomparable 109: Evil, Surfing Ronald McDonald
item.author: Jason Snell
item.description: Soon to be a major motion picture you probably shouldn't see, David Mitchell's 2004 novel "Cloud Atlas" is in our sights. This novel consists of six separate stories set in different genres and timeframes from the 1850s to a post-apocalyptic future, and yet they're all interlinked. Somehow. It's fun, weird, and challenging, but what does it all mean? Read it now before every character in it becomes Tom Hanks and Halle Berry.
item.content:encoded:
Soon to be a major motion picture you probably shouldn't see, David Mitchell's 2004 novel "Cloud Atlas" is in our sights. This novel consists of six separate stories set in different genres and timeframes from the 1850s to a post-apocalyptic future, and yet they're all interlinked. Somehow. It's fun, weird, and challenging, but what does it all mean? Read it now before every character in it becomes Tom Hanks and Halle Berry.

Links for this episode:

  • "Cloud Atlas" on Amazon.com
  • "Cloud Atlas" movie trailer
item.itunes:author: Jason Snell
item.itunes:subtitle: David Mitchell's 2004 novel "Cloud Atlas."

This novel consists of six separate stories set in different genres and timeframes from the 1850s to a post-apocalyptic future, and yet they're all interlinked. Somehow. It's fun, weird, and challenging, but what does it all mean? Read it now before every character in it becomes Tom Hanks and Halle Berry.
item.itunes:keywords: books, movies, tv, comics, sci-fi, geek

item.title: The Nickel 30: Here's The Pitch
item.author: Will Carroll
item.description: Will and Scott don't ignore football, bringing back the refs, or the zeitgeist of sports, but they are going baseball heavy this week as MLB goes into its final week. We check out the playoff picture with Rob Neyer of SB Nation and Ian Casselberry of Bleacher Report. Don't swing and miss as The Nickel makes it's pitch.
item.content:encoded: Will and Scott don't ignore football, bringing back the refs, or the zeitgeist of sports, but they are going baseball heavy this week as MLB goes into its final week. item.title: The Critical Path 56: Strategic Disadvantages: A discussion with James Allworth
item.author: Horace Dediu & Dan Benjamin
item.description: James Allworth, Harvard Business School Forum for Growth and Innovation fellow and co-author of How Will You Measure Your Life joins Horace for an in-depth discussion of the vulnerability of Apple to low-end disruption. Specifically, assuming the iPhone reaches a point of over-service, did Apple arm its suppliers with the means to create its replacement? We dip into case studies of Dell, HP, HTC and Microsoft and touch on how iPod escaped this fate.
item.content:encoded:
James Allworth, Harvard Business School Forum for Growth and Innovation fellow and co-author of How Will You Measure Your Life joins Horace for an in-depth discussion of the vulnerability of Apple to low-end disruption. Specifically, assuming the iPhone reaches a point of over-service, did Apple arm its suppliers with the means to create its replacement? We dip into case studies of Dell, HP, HTC and Microsoft and touch on how iPod escaped this fate.

Links for this episode:

  • What is Apple's real Strategic Advantage?
  • John Gruber's "The New Apple Advantage"

Sponsored by Igloo Software, Harvest (use code 5by5 for 50% off first month), Gazelle, and MailChimp.

item.title: Screen Time 7: The Genre of "Looper" (with director Rian Johnson)
item.author: Moisés Chiullan
item.description: Moisés interviews Looper director Rian Johnson, gives his initial reactions to Cloud Atlas (from the directors of The Matrix trilogy), and covers the week's home video releases, including Bond 50, David Fincher's The Game, and The Dark Knight Returns Part 1. The spoiler-free Rian Johnson interview starts at around 24:30 in case you'd like to skip ahead. A spoiler-laden After Dark will be posted later this weekend with massive spoiler warnings.
item.content:encoded:
Moisés interviews Looper director Rian Johnson, gives his initial reactions to Cloud Atlas (from the directors of The Matrix trilogy), and covers the week's home video releases, including Bond 50, David Fincher's The Game, and The Dark Knight Returns Part 1. item.title: The Web Ahead 36: Sass with Scott Kellum
item.author: Jen Simmons
item.description: CSS preprocessors are becoming very popular very quickly. Many front-end developers are finding them invaluable for coding increasingly-complex sites. Scott Kellum joins Jen Simmons to talk about Sass and Compass, what they offer, how to get started, and why you might want to consider adding such tools to your workflow
item.content:encoded:
CSS preprocessors are becoming very popular very quickly. Many front-end developers are finding them invaluable for coding increasingly-complex sites. Scott Kellum joins Jen Simmons to talk about Sass and Compass, what they offer, how to get started, and why you might want to consider adding such tools to your workflow

item.title: Back to Work 86: The Talmud of Claremont
item.author: Merlin Mann & Dan Benjamin
item.description:
TOPIC: Anxious about the Change
This week Merlin updates Dan about his schedule changes. They're going to come, but it's probably the anxiety, not the change, that is the problem. Take heart, it may be the change that you need.
While you're at it, take the opportunity to plan your buffers and ramp up times. Your schedule will work better, your vacation may be less stressful, your pie will stay alive.
Bonus: Dan and Merlin's comic book recommendations for new readers.
item.content:encoded:
TOPIC: Anxious about the Change

This week Merlin updates Dan about his schedule changes. They're going to come, but it's probably the anxiety, not the change, that is the problem. Take heart, it may be the change that you need.

While you're at it, take the opportunity to plan your buffers and ramp up times. Your schedule will work better, your vacation may be less stressful, your pie will stay alive.

Bonus: Dan and Merlin's comic book recommendations for new readers.

item.title: Build and Analyze 96: Sandwich With A Slot
item.author: Marco Arment & Dan Benjamin
item.description: Dan and Marco discuss initial impressions of the iPhone 5, rapid iOS 6 adoption and when it may be safe to require it, Feedburner's demise, B.S. in Computer Science degrees versus related degrees with lower math and theory requirements, and the economics of limited-edition apps.
item.content:encoded:
Dan and Marco discuss initial impressions of the iPhone 5, rapid iOS 6 adoption and when it may be safe to require it, Feedburner's demise, B.S. in Computer Science degrees versus related degrees with lower math and theory requirements, and the economics of limited-edition apps.

item.title: Screen Time 6: The New Version of Hollywood
item.author: Moisés Chiullan
item.description: Moisés talks about the movie business with producer Keith Calder (You're Next, The Greatest Movie Ever Sold). They discuss the film business as a whole, from distribution and content to how movies are rapidly becoming more of a digital medium than film-based. From innovative new distribution options to piracy to major studio tentpoles with no soul, they leave no part of the business untouched.
item.content:encoded:
Moisés talks about the movie business with producer Keith Calder (You're Next, The Greatest Movie Ever Sold). They discuss the film business as a whole, from distribution and content to how movies are rapidly becoming more of a digital medium than film-based. From innovative new distribution options to piracy to major studio tentpoles with no soul, they leave no part of the business untouched.

item.title: The Critical Path 55: Gravity Well
item.author: Horace Dediu & Dan Benjamin
item.description: Horace and Moisés discuss the early consumer response to iOS 6 (Maps in particular), and how people appear to greatly prefer native apps to their web app counterparts. They also dig into just how large an opportunity cost Apple is capable of absorbing in the interest of protecting their platform. In doing so, they examine the native app vs. HTML5 debate.
item.content:encoded:
Horace and Moisés discuss the early consumer response to iOS 6 (Maps in particular), and how people appear to greatly prefer native apps to their web app counterparts. They also dig into just how large an opportunity cost Apple is capable of absorbing in the interest of protecting their platform. In doing so, they examine the native app vs. HTML5 debate.

Links for this episode:

  • Why is there no iPhone 5? | Asycmo (Oct 2011)

Sponsored by Treehouse, Gazelle, Hover.com (coupon code DANSENTME for 10% off), and Squarespace.com (coupon code DANSENTME9 for 10% off).
item.itunes:author: Horace Dediu & Dan Benjamin
item.itunes:subtitle: Horace and Moisés discuss the early consumer response to iOS 6, Apple's protection of its platform, and how the company has built an annual upgrade strategy in the US.
item.itunes:summary: Horace and Moisés discuss the early consumer response to iOS 6 (Maps in particular), and how people appear to greatly prefer native apps to their web app counterparts. They also dig into just how large an opportunity cost Apple is capable of absorbing in the interest of protecting their platform. In doing so, they examine the native app vs. HTML5 debate.
